unnormalised: My first experience with Indian Airways, specifically flight AI-442 from Delhi to Mumbai, wasn't exactly smooth sailing. I'd booked the ticket on 10/07/2024, expecting a reasonably comfortable journey. After all, it was a 9:00 AM flight, giving me the whole day to settle into Mumbai. I even shelled out an extra ₹1500 for a window seat, dreaming of catching a glimpse of the Arabian Sea.
normalised: My first experience with Indian Airways, specifically flight A-I- four hundred and forty two from Delhi to Mumbai, wasn't exactly smooth sailing. I'd booked the ticket on tenth july two thousand and twenty four, expecting a reasonably comfortable journey. After all, it was a nine A-M flight, giving me the whole day to settle into Mumbai. I even shelled out an extra rupee one thousand five hundred for a window seat, dreaming of catching a glimpse of the Arabian Sea.

unnormalised: The initial hiccup came in the form of a delayed departure. The announcement crackled through the Indira Gandhi International Airport at approximately 8:30 AM, informing us that the flight was delayed by 2 hours due to "operational reasons." Of course, no further explanation was given, leaving a sea of frustrated passengers milling around Gate 5B. A quick scan of the departures board confirmed the bad news. My arrival time was now estimated to be around 1:00 PM, messing up all my meticulously planned meetings.
normalised: The initial hiccup came in the form of a delayed departure. The announcement crackled through the Indira Gandhi International Airport at approximately eight thirty A-M, informing us that the flight was delayed by two hours due to "operational reasons." Of course, no further explanation was given, leaving a sea of frustrated passengers milling around Gate five B. A quick scan of the departures board confirmed the bad news. My arrival time was now estimated to be around one P-M, messing up all my meticulously planned meetings.

unnormalised: Adding insult to injury, the promised complimentary breakfast was a sad excuse for a meal. A tiny, rock-hard vada pav, accompanied by a lukewarm cup of chai. My stomach grumbled in protest. I watched, with envy, as the gentleman in seat 23A devoured his homemade paratha, clearly a seasoned traveler accustomed to anticipating such disappointments.

unnormalised: Once airborne, the in-flight entertainment system decided to malfunction. A flickering screen displaying a loop of static and error messages was the only offering. I had envisioned catching up on some Bollywood movies, but alas, it wasn’t to be. Instead, I was left to contemplate the fluffy clouds outside, a decidedly less engaging alternative.

unnormalised: However, it wasn't all bad. The cabin crew, despite the chaos, were remarkably polite and efficient. A young lady named Priya Sharma patiently answered everyone's queries, offering apologies for the delay and ensuring we had enough water and blankets. Her dedication to her job, even under such stressful circumstances, was truly commendable. She even managed to find me a slightly softer vada pav from the dwindling supply.

unnormalised: Despite the initial setbacks and minor annoyances – the delay, the breakfast, the faulty entertainment – I arrived in Mumbai, albeit a bit later than planned. While the experience wasn't perfect, it was certainly memorable. And, well, it gave me a story to tell, didn't it? Maybe next time, I'll just take the train; the 16-hour journey might actually be less stressful.
